data.title: Immigrant Benevolent Organizations
data.text:
Landsmanschaft — Immigrant Benevolent Organizations

· Part I: Introduction

· Part II: Directory of Landmanschaften Organizations

· Part III: Addendum

· Bibliography

A landsmanschaft [Yiddish: לאַנדסמאַנשאפט, plural: landsmanschaften לאַנדסמאַנשאפטען] is an immigrant benevolent organization, formed by ex-residents of the same locality or town (לאַנדסמאַן landsman, plural: לאַנדסלײַט landsleit). These aid organizations were established to deal with social, economic, and cultural problems, and provided a social framework for mutual assistance.

Part I: Introduction

by Glenda Rubin, San Francisco Bay Area, October 24, 1996.

The moment immigrants arrived, they invoked their custom of self-segregation by shtetl – town of origin – which is said to be rooted in the tradition of the self-contained societies in Eastern Europe. In their new lands, they joined "landsmanschaft" societies.

For details about landsmanschaft societies, see די אידישע לאנדסמאנשאפטען פון ניו יאָרק [Di Idishe landsmanshaften fun Nyu York = The Jewish Landsmanschaften of New York], prepared by the Yiddish Writers' Group of the Federal Writers' Project, Works Progress Administration, published by the I.L. Peretz Yiddish Writers' Group, 1938.

The book has four main parts:

Articles (in Yiddish) on such subjects as landsmanschaftan present status, landsmanschaftan and immigration, landsmanschaftan and relief organizations, landsmanschaftan constitutions, landsmanschaftan federations, folklore of the Jewish community, landsmanschaftan social role, and landsmanschaftan restaurants.

A literature section (in Yiddish) with some essays and an anthology of poetry.

A directory (in Yiddish) with a brief paragraph on individual organizations that generally includes the following data: frequency and location of meetings, year founded with number of members, current number of members, % American born members, % members not landsleit, language the meetings are conducted in, other activities, e.g.: cultural activities, burial and death benefits, aid for the ill.

An English listing. These are "one-liners" of over 750 landsmanschaften organizations. The only information included here is the name of the group, and the first initial, last name, and address of the secretary. In addition to landsmanschaften, it also includes similar listings for over 300 ladies' auxiliaries, 200 Workmen's Circle branches, 15 Jewish National Workers' Alliance groups, and 70 IWO (International Workers Order) branches.

Part II: Directory of Landmanschaften Organizations

This list of landmanschaften organizations in Israel is edited from published sources, circa 1996. Be aware that persons named on this list may be elderly, frail or likely deceased. Please use utmost consideration when sending an inquiry.
